text:
All right, welcome, everybody. Thank you for being here. It is my honor to introduce
you to Larry Summers.

Larry is no stranger
to, I think, everybody in this audience. He was the Secretary
of the Treasury

from 1999 through 2001. He was the 27th president
of Harvard University.

He then was the director of
the National Economic Council.

And prior to all of that,
he was a renowned scholar and deep thinker on many,
many issues in economics,

and continues to be today. And that's why we have him here. He is well-known
as a deep thinker

on all issues that are
troubling us in the economy

and in public health today. And so speaking for
myself, it feels

like today, there is enormous
amounts of data and news coming our way, and
we're bombarded with it.

And yet, we're all
seeking more clarity, and there's less clarity today
than I think there ever was.

Last, I wanted to say Larry
is a great friend of HBS, and every time we've
asked him to speak

in front of groups like
this, he has been there to share his ideas.

So we have about
45 minutes today, with me asking some questions. And then we're going to
open it up to the audience

and try to broker some Q&A
and take your questions. We'll be doing that by
looking at the chat,

and also please using
the raised hand features. So I'd like to cover
a lot of ground--

so starting with
the health crisis, moving to economic policy,
politics, financial markets,

and then a last word
on what all of this means for higher education.

I think it makes sense
to start with health. And so, Larry, you've
written over the past month

about the trade-off
between our response on the public health
side and economic policy.

And I think you've been
quite persuasive in arguing that there's actually less of a
trade-off than one might think,

and that, in fact, one needs
to fight the virus first. Do you do you
still believe that?

And what's the point at which
one has to open up the economy

and draw the trade-off
the other way? Robin, let me just
first say that I'm

glad to be here, glad to
be with so many friends-- even if I can't see them--

from HBS-- especially
glad to be here with you. And let me say that these
events are not a huge surprise.

When I was president
of the university, I used to say that
global health should be a major priority
for the university,

because the two most
important things that we're going to happen in
the 21st century were the rise of the
developing world and the fact

that it was going to be
a century of biology, in the same way that
the 20th century was a century of physics--

and that those two
things were going to come together around
the global health issues.

We did some calculations
a few years ago that demonstrated that, on a
go-forward present value basis,

the consequences
of future pandemics were in the same range as the
consequences of climate change,

but the degree of effort
going into climate change was an order of
magnitude or two greater.

I think, on the specific
question you asked, the people who frame
the question in the way

you suggest-- that somehow, we
can help the economy by worrying less about
health and opening up

more aggressively-- I think they miss two
fundamental things. First, they miss
that mostly, it's

not our policy that's reducing
the performance of the economy.

It's the disease itself. You can open up the
economy all you want,

but when they're hiring
extra refrigerator trucks to take care of dead bodies and
transport them to the morgues,

not very many people
are going to decide to go out of their houses. Not many people are
going to go shopping

when they think 10%
of their neighbors have a potentially fatal
contagious disease.

So blaming the economic
collapse on the policy, rather than on the problem,
is fallacious in the same way

that observing that, wherever
you see a lot of oncologists, you'll tend to see a lot
of people dying of cancer

and inferring that that means
that oncologists kill people-- it's just a fallacy. Second thing that's
fallacious is, yeah,

we can create a near-term
bit of economic growth

by letting it all go,
but if that leads us back to the widespread spread of
contagious disease, ultimately,

we're going to be behind. I had the bad luck to
rupture both my quad tendons a year ago.

I was really eager to get
back to playing tennis, to get back to
doing things I like. I was pounding on my physicians
to let me take the brace off.

And they said, look, you
can take the brace off and you might
enjoy the next day, but you're really going to
hate it when you reinjure

the tendons and you're back
to zero with weakened tendons

and having to go through the
whole rehab process again. Well, it's the same logic here.

There will come
a point when it's right to open up the economy. There might even be some debate
about what that point is.

But no one who
sensibly looks at data could possibly believe
that that point

is this week or next week. And so that's what I mean
when I say right now,

the decision would
be just same if you were trying to maximize
society's welfare

or if you were trying to
maximize the present value of future GDP. Either way, you have to knock
the prevalence of the virus

down. Are you saying that the decision
isn't really lockdown or no

lockdown-- it's
really 85% lockdown that we would do anyway
versus 99% lockdown

that the government suggests? That's not what I just said,
but I would agree with that.

I suspect, if we were
better at lockdown, we would be able to move
out of lockdown faster.

Look, some of it's probably
cultural about Americans, but when the state of
Florida is deciding

that professional wrestling
is a necessary activity, when

people across the
country are deciding that liquor stores
and nail salons

are essential businesses
that need to be kept open, we are just raising the
amount of social contact,

and therefore,
delaying the moment when we get this under control.

So we could be doing
this much better. You spent much of your
career in the government,

and particularly, the
federal government. What do you make of the states
leading the COVID response,

relative to the federal
government, at least in the United States?

I think, if we had a more
competent federal government, there would be more reliance
on the federal government

and there would be
more efficiency, because we'd have more coherent
and centralized policies

on things where there
really are gains to scale, like producing ventilators, or
arranging large-scale testing
apparatuses, or procuring masks.

On the other hand,
the more there are differences in attitudes
in different places,

the more it makes sense to
have locally differentiated policies. And in the United
States, we've now

got radically
different views if you look at different
parts of the country,

so it's sort of figures
that you're going to have more decentralized solutions. On balance, I
think we'd probably

be better off if the federal
government was more competent and taking more responsibility.

And when we do come
out of lockdown, what is that going to be like?

How do you think we're
going to do it safely? I know mostly, we're going to
be talking about economics here,

but there are a bunch
of different plans. First of all, I'm not sure
we are going to do it safely.

Second, even if we do it
safely, I think, in most things,

including my recovery
from my ruptured tendons, it's not a steady march
from darkness into light.

It's not a steady march uphill. It's three steps up, one or
two steps down, three steps up.

So I think we're going to
see a series of movements

in both directions,
and there are going to be moments
when we step too far and we have to then
lock things down.

By the way, if there were
no moments when we had to lock things down, it would--

in some area, it
would probably mean that we weren't moving rapidly
enough as we move forward.

But I think this is going to
be a pretty gradual process. It's going to be more people
can go outside and go shopping.

It's going to be quite
a while before you're going to see a large
number of people
in a small amount of area.

If I had to bet, I'm guessing-- I don't remember--
that the big conference

room that HBS uses a lot
in Spangler, I would guess, can seat 300 or 400
people for a meal.

I would be surprised-- quite surprised, if in calendar
2020, that room at any point

had more than 75 people in it. So let me turn to
questions of policy.

If you were Treasury
Secretary today, what would you be most
worried about over the coming
months and years? I think probably, I would be--

depends on exactly how
you ask the question. At one level, what I
would be worried about

was that the global
system was going to be caused to collapse by this--

that we were going to
mismanage, and China was going to mismanage the US-China
relationship into a new Cold

War and complete backstop-- backdrop from
globalization, and that that

was going to have
consequences that were going to go far beyond this.

At a second level,
I'd be worried that a country that can
do extraordinary things

was somehow going to suffer
substantially economically,

was going to lose a
substantial number of lives, and was going to seem slightly
pathetic to the world,

because it was unable
to produce enough swabs, unable to produce
enough of masks,

and unwilling to invest
with sufficient money

and with sufficient coherence
and force from the government

to be able to perform the
very simple task of getting

a large number of people
tested for a deadly disease.

So at a different level,
I'd be worried about that. And then, within
my remit, I would

be worried that we didn't
have clear enough thinking

and adequate enough systems
to make money flow to people

who needed it, and not flow
to people who did not need it.

I would find the
spectacle of hedge funds

being eligible for the
PPP pretty disturbing.

I would find the spectacle
of Harvard professors with small consulting
businesses who

had a couple of employees being
able to get two months payroll for those employees
from the taxpayers

as a grant to be
pretty appalling.

I would find the idea that
the Boeing Corporation was going to get tens of billions
of dollars that was not

going to come at the
expense of shareholders, after everything
that it happened, to be pretty disturbing.

And at the same
time, I'd be looking at the poor guy who
ran a pizza shop

at a disadvantaged
neighborhood, who couldn't quite fight his way through
the system at JP Morgan,

to get his $32,000 to
keep the three people who

worked for him going-- I would find that
pretty disturbing.

This is a great set of questions
around business failure and the inevitable
business failure

that we're going to have coming. And you referenced
a small business. Large business-- we
have a Chapter 11 system

that works reasonably well. I guess there's two
things I'd like to know. One is, are you confident
that the Chapter 11

system would be a good one for
dealing with large companies? And in terms of the
smaller businesses,

your example of Larry's
Pizza with three employees-- what's the right way to handle
that business versus the larger

businesses in the economy? I think, in general, there
has been an excessive view

in some quarters that we
should be trying to save every business and every job.

In the typical month in
the American economy,

about 4 million
people leave a job. So in a typical year,
a third of the people--

a third of the jobs in
the country are left. If you look in a
variety of industries,

there's very, very
high turnover of firms. So even in the
best of times, it's

not that all the
existing establishments are frozen in place.

I think there are mechanisms
that allow these things to be worked through.

Yeah, somebody may be able to
not be able to pay their rent, but in the current
environment, what's

the landlord going to do? Maybe he or she can
evict them, but if they do, how are they ever going to
get another tenant in there?

And so riding along
with this tenant's probably the best strategy.

So I think we need
to put a lot of money in to stimulate
purchasing power. I think we need to
put a lot of money

in to protect every worker's
possessing a reasonable income.

I think we've got to
put a lot of money into state and
local governments, on whom poor people depend for
their basic standard of living.

But I don't think we need to put
grant money, money that's not

coming back to the government,
into large numbers of companies

on a very large scale. Yes, there should be some of
that money going into the pizza shops, but I think, when we're
doing business with substantial

companies, the government
should be a preferred creditor, where possible, should
have preferred interests,

where possible, or security, and
the government should be taking warrants in those
companies so that,

in the places
where it succeeds-- which I suspect will
be a fair number-- taxpayers are better off.

You take the TARP in
aggregate-- the bank bailouts, automobile bailouts, all that--

the government, on average,
made money on all of that.

And so I think that's what
we should be trying to do. Things may end up tougher, and
we may not exactly make money,

but I think these ideas
around large-scale transfers to business are
very problematic.

This principle
that the government needs to make money
out of it-- it's true that, in 2007 and
2008, the programs that

were enacted-- overall,
the government made money on those programs. Are you extending that to
the pizza shops, or is that--

we should be willing to lose
some money on the smallest-- I think we should
be willing to lose some money for the
smallest businesses,

but we need to be careful
as we go about losing money.

I obviously would
never make the claim, but a government
program where I'd be able to make a claim
for my research assistants

doesn't seem to me to be
a well-designed government program.

Sounds like you
basically want capitalism to do what capitalism
does, and then

to help the most
vulnerable in our society, whether those be the smallest
business owners, or employees,

and so on. I think that's the generally
right economic philosophy,

and I think we
make a mistake when we say it's really
important-- therefore,

we're going to forget
about market principles.

I think we should be trying to
pay very generously for swabs,
and for masks, and for tests.

One of the many things that's
causing that to be difficult is there's a sense that, if
you invest in advance to have

an inventory of those things
in a moment like this, people are going
to say, well, thank you very much for
having done that,

and we'll be happy to take
it from you at marginal cost. So I think we need to think very
carefully about the incentives

we create for people who want
to prepare for a disaster that might happen, and
might not happen.

Yeah. That's something that we should
be willing to lose money on. Expected returns on
holding stockpiles should be low or negative.

Turning to the Fed, what do
you make of the Fed's response

to what's happened? And particularly, I
think the audience here would be interested in
understanding parallels

to 2008, and whether those
parallels have been stretched.

What's your overall assessment
of what the Fed has done? Well, first of all, just
in terms of walls of money,

or towers of money,
compared to history,

what we've done
this year has been the Himalayas, what we did
in 2008 was the Rockies,

and everything else was
the foothills of Vermont. So we are getting to more and
more and more unprecedented

territory. I would have done
things very, very much

like what the Fed did. But I think, when we're
declaring whatever it takes,

in terms of central bank
activity once a decade-- which seems to be the new
normal here, after Mario Draghi,

and now-- what we're
going through now-- I think there's going to need
to be a lot of soul searching

and thinking about the
way our financial system

is functioning. In the midst of
all this, I don't think there's really
a viable alternative,

but I do wonder about a world
where the Federal Reserve is

buying exchange traded
funds whose only asset is

high-yield bonds
represented by companies

who are on all sides of
those various transactions.

So I think we're going to have
to have a lot of soul searching afterwards about what our
principles exactly are,

because many of the principles
we thought we had before,

we have crossed. There's a heated argument
about the decision

as to whether the Fed
could or could not have bailed out Lehman
legally, and whether whatever

was legal-- whether it would or
would not have been appropriate to bail out Lehman.

We are far, far beyond, in terms
of the breadth of the Fed's intervention in the
economy, where we

were, with respect to Lehman. Or to put it another way, in
terms of government deficits,

we are closer to the
post-Pearl Harbor period than to the post-Lehman period,
in terms of the amount by which

and the speed with which the
government is ratcheting up

spending. I do think there should
be some change of focus

back to the health issue. The truth is that, if I'm
scared because I think

I might die if I go to
the store or go to my job, you can do whatever you
want with the interest rate

and you can do whatever you
want with the government budget deficit, but the economy's
not going to be very good.

And I think, if we're able to
get people's confidence back around the health, the recovery
can be somewhat more rapid

than people suppose. People often suggest, well,
recoveries are always slow.

Well, not all recoveries
everywhere are so slow. I'm talking here from
Truro, Massachusetts.

Truro, Massachusetts has
a depression from October to May of every year, and then
there's massive economic growth

from May to June
and June to July, and then it's back
to the depression.

Yeah, but Truro,
Massachusetts plans for that. Yeah, sure. Sure.

So it's going to be
easier, but a lot of the people who are
closed now can be planning

to reopen at some point. So yes, we have to have
a lot of liquidity.

I'm not disputing that. The point I'm making is that,
if we put the health problems

credibly behind us
and people believe we're going to be able to put
the health problems credibly

behind us, then we will be
able to engage in exactly

that kind of planning. And then, I think
our recovery could be more rapid than it was.

But I'm not sure any of
that's going to happen, because I'm not sure
how clearly we're doing the requisite kind of planning.

Is there going to be
inflation this time? So with the Fed
balance sheet growing at a rate that is higher than
in the financial crisis--

there was lots of discussion
about whether the Fed was overreaching and there was going
to be inflation that turned out

not to be. Is this time different? I thought, in 2009
and 2010, the people

who were excited that
this was going to produce really high inflation--

many of whom, I have to say,
were graduates of your school--

had not done a good job
studying their courses-- that, if they had
done a reasonable job

studying monetary
economics, they would have understood that,
A, when money pays interest,

there isn't the same urge
to disgorge it quickly, and so a large Fed
balance sheet--

there's no particular
reason why it needs to be inflationary; and
B, that the Federal Reserve had

tools, in terms of the ability
to manage interest rates, that

would enable it to contain
any incipient inflation

and so I thought the people
who were warning then were basically foolish.

And history has
worn out that view, in the sense that none of
the major central banks

can basically get to
their 2% inflation target.

I think it's more complicated
this time, because this time,

there's a substantial
element of supply shock. The fact that a third of
the people in the economy

can't go to work means that
the potential production of the economy is much lower.

And we're doing a great deal to
boost demand with all these tax

cuts and all these
various lending and stimulating programs.

So I would guess that we're
headed into a continuing

deflationary-- or not deflationary--
disinflationary period

around the world. I was warning a year ago about
Japanification and black hole

monetary economics of
zero interest rates, and it seems to me,
this has done more

to reinforce that than
it does to operate in the other direction.

But I certainly think the
risks of accelerating inflation

or high inflation are
higher than they were-- than I thought they
were three months ago.

Sorry. On the-- We're in a very funny world
that we don't really-- at least I don't feel like
I have experience with.

One of the things
people say is, when we get such large
national debts,

there's an inevitable tendency
to want to inflate them away. Well, the Bank of Japan has
been trying to get the inflation

rate up even just a little
bit for a decade now, and they haven't
been able to do it.

So that makes these
easily-uttered sentences about inflating away debt
and the like at least

carry more
uncertainty with them. So on your earlier
comment that overall, this

tends to push the
other direction, did you have in mind
there that the level

of precautionary saving in
the economy is going to go up, and that's going to put
further negative pressure

on the real rate? What exactly do
you have in mind? I had in mind two
and a half things.

I think that there's going
to be more uncertainty, which is going to operate
to raise saving. I think there's going to
be more opportunity-- more

savings propensity. I think there's going
to see more uncertainty, and that's going to operate
to reduce investment.

And those two
things together are going to reinforce the
various secular stagnation

arguments that I've been
making for a number of years. So I think we're going
to see less investment,

and more liquidity flowing into
existing assets, which means more bubble risks and the like.

The very high levels
of share repurchases you were seeing just prior
to this pandemic, almost all

of which were
financed by leverage, are an illustration of
exactly that principle.

Yeah, I think it basically
comes down centrally to the increased
uncertainty and the tendency

to that meaning lower
saving and lower investment.

I would kind of guess
that this is also,

on net, going to reinforce the
demassification of the economy.

You're going to see more
Zoom conferences, and fewer conferences in hotels.

You're going to see more
e-commerce, and less retail

commerce. Those tendencies
are going to operate in the direction of reducing
the neutral real interest rates.

So I think we're
headed into a world of negative neutral
real interest

rates, considerable
difficulty for central banks in raising inflation rates.

I think it's going to be a
macroeconomically complicated world, where most of
the action is going

to be in things that
are blurring together

fiscal and monetary policy. When the Fed buys junk bonds,
that's blurring together fiscal

and monetary policy,
because they're-- you can think of that as
buying a safe bond plus giving

a substantial credit subsidy. When the treasury issues 10-year
notes and the Fed buys them,

that's another kind
of blurring together of fiscal and monetary policy.

So I think we're
going to be living in a world of much
more hybrid policies

than has been traditional. So just to clarify
for the audience here, that logic
about, as we all--

suppose we all decide to
start working from home-- the idea is just that it's going
to be a less capital-intensive

society? We don't need the office
buildings and the parking lots, and so on net--

The office computers that
are separate from the home computers-- so I
mean, these things

have been in train for a
substantial period of time.

A large bank that
I work with now has 3/4 as many offices for its
relatively high-level people

as it did before because
it's got a set of technology where you can walk
into an office,

and you can hit a button
and type in a code, and then all of a sudden,
pictures of your wife

and your children appear
on the electronic frames. And the computer comes up and
says, welcome, Mr. Summers,

and gives you access
to all your files. And if somebody walks into
that office five minutes later,

it looks like it's yours. And in the presence
of that technology, they don't need to occupy
nearly as much space

as they did before. Well, the world of
Zoom is going to be a world that's going to
take that one step further.

What is your view of what's
happening at the local level and the local governments?

Many of them are not collecting
tax revenues to the extent that they were before, and many
local and state governments

were already in
pretty rough shape. All this being reflected
in the current muni markets

and the pricing of
muni debt, where do you think this is headed?

Where it should be headed is
the federal government should be making substantial
resources available to them,

whether as grants, or
whether as extra support

for their Medicaid
programs, or by allowing

some reduction of the
balanced budget amendments that many of them live with.

You can debate the idea that,
you can make good arguments on both sides that, at a
downturn moment like this,

is a good or a bad idea to start
making additional investments in infrastructure.

I tend to think
it is, but that's something that reasonable
people can certainly debate.

But it's hard to believe
that this is a good moment to stop maintaining the highways
and eliminating potholes,

as more and more
people are out of work. It's hard to believe that
this is a good moment when

municipal hospitals should
be tightening their budgets. That's just hard to believe.

And we just need
to figure out how to be countercyclical in
what happens at the state

and local government. Or even, it'd be good enough
if we just figured out

to not be pro-cyclical,
in terms of what happens to state and local governments.

And this would also be a moment,
since the federal government's providing money--

some influence comes with that-- to improve practices
in a variety of areas
in the state and local sector.

But I think it's just tragic to
see these jurisdictions being

forced to cut their
budgets at the very moment when their revenues are least
and their needs are greatest.

And it seems to me it
would be the beginnings of a rational society to
find ways of avoiding that.

Let me turn to the
financial markets. So it's been a puzzling
month for many of us

following the markets. I want to start with
the equity markets, and then maybe talk a little
bit about other markets--

in particular, energy. But if you have a
simple present value model, such as we do
in a HBS classroom,

with a real discount rate of 8%
and a real growth rate of 3%, that gives you a multiple of 20.

And so the first year is
roughly 5% of total value.

And of course, the first
year could be negative, and so maybe it's 10%, if
it's the same as last year,

but with the opposite sign. But markets were
down nearly 40%, and now they're back up
to a cumulative drawdown

of about 15%. What do you make of the-- what's
happening in the stock market

overall? Look, Jack Meyer used to
run the Harvard endowment,

and he was very successful in
running the Harvard endowment. And one of the
secrets of his success

was he never invested
on the basis of anything that anybody in the
Economics Department said.

So do not take anything I'm
saying as investment advice.

I think the general experience-- pretty universal experience--
is that serious recessions come

with serious market downturns. And 15% is not a
serious market downturn.

I think the general experience
is that serious recessions come

with market downturns that
include many false dawns.

There were five rallies
of more than 25% between October of 1929 and July
of 1932, one of which was 93%.

There was a 27% rally
from a point after Lehman

until the beginning of 2009,
when the market started

to go sharply down again. So point 1-- serious recessions
come with serious downturns.

Point 2-- there are
a lot of false dawns. Point 3-- for reasons that
economists can debate--

I wrote a number of papers
at one stage about so-called hysteresis theories--

the evidence is pretty strong
that, when there's a recession, we don't ever quite get back
to the previous trend line.

We might grow as fast as we
did before the recession, but we never get back anywhere
near the previous trend line.

If you look today-- not today-- if you looked
at the end of 2019,

at where was US GDP
relative to the trend line

that somebody would have
plotted before the 2008 financial crisis, the answer
is it was way below, 12% below,

15%. Yeah, that's a stunning
picture, but the for-profits--

And you'd find something
similar for many different-- if you looked at many different
recessions-- that, in general,

you ended up below
the trend line.

So when I see the
most serious recession we've had since the
Second World War,

I think it's more likely
than not that we'll have a pretty substantial,
at least modestly sustained

market decline. And so from that
perspective, I've been surprised by the
bounce from the bottom.

And I also tend
to think that it's a broad lesson of financial
history that the Fed can--

the Fed, and the power of
liquidity, and all of that can matter for a while, but
it can't matter forever.

And so given those
circumstances,

I would be skeptical
about either inferring as an investor, that
we've seen the worst

and all was well, or as
